awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Spatially Modulated Light For Trapping And Addressing Of Alkaline-Earth Neutral Atom Qubits
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will result from the development of a scalable, universal quantum computing platform. The range of applications are broad and will expand in parallel with the development of new quantum algorithms, with initial applications including molecular simulations for the chemical and pharmaceutical industries, currently limited by the approximations necessary to make calculations tractable for classical computers. In order to perform these simulations at a scale useful for commercial applications, quantum computing must be significantly scaled. The proposed system will develop a new method to trap and control individual atoms for scaling of quantum computers.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will develop technology for parallel, high-fidelity single- and multi-qubit gates in neutral atom quantum computers. The technology will enable neutral atoms as a platform for scalable quantum computing technology with fault-tolerant capabilities.  The proposed project includes: 1) development of systems to control atomic qubits in parallel; 2) a methodology to enact high-fidelity gates; and 3) development of necessary infrastructure for a cloud-accessed quantum computer.  With a previously unrealized degree of coherent control to atomic systems, the proposed system will serve as an entirely novel tool to study many-body physics, enabling new quantum simulations of new phases of matter or high-energy physics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Atom Computing has developed enabling technology for the use of optically-trapped alkaline-earth neutral atoms as a quantum computing platform. Neutral atoms provide a pathway to highly-scalable qubit platforms, which is a requirement for commercially-viable quantum computing. During our Phase-II SBIR project, we have proven out nuclear spin qubits in alkaline-earth atoms as a highly-scalable, highly-coherent qubit platform, experimentally demonstrating coherence times at the 10’s of seconds scale and demonstrating individual qubit control. Utilizing atom identification followed by dynamic atom rearrangement, we have demonstrated routine operation with defect-free arrays of qubits and have demonstrated the ability to trap more than 100 atomic qubits in an array. We have developed the optical systems for individual-atom addressing and demonstrated the control over individual qubits necessary for quantum computing gate operations.

 

In addition to the instrumentation and implementation of gate operations, we have built out a software stack necessary to deliver a quantum computing service. This includes the infrastructure to enable automation and calibration to ensure uptime and high-fidelity, calibrated operations. We have also built out higher levels of our software stack to enable users to program circuits and quantum algorithms. Additionally, the upper layers of the software stack build towards interfaces with third-party software platforms and software development kits.

 


Last Modified: 06/30/2022
Modified by: Jonathan King
